text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
esoteric warfare is the latest
full-length LP from famed Norwegian
black metal outfit mayhem this band's
career dates back to the 80s they are
one of the original black metal outfits
out of Norway this is their first
full-length LP in seven years I believe
however it is not uncommon to have a bit
of a wide gap in time between releases
the band's existence has been nothing if
not turbulent they're truly a group that
lives up to the name they slap
themselves with not only with how
they've experimented with their sound on
various records dabbling a little in
electronics and avant-garde metal and
spoken word but they're sometimes
violent breakups and lineup changes have
been the biggest contributor to the
folklore of that which is mayhem like a
photograph of one of the band's earliest
members dead being featured on the front
cover of the live bootleg dawn of the
black hearts the issue with this photo
is that it's a picture of him after
having committed suicide or another
early member of the group Euronymous
having been murdered in cold blood by
Varg Vickery's AKA Burzum both of whom
perform on Mayhem's infamous debut album
and the most recent change to befall
this LP has been the loss of longtime
guitarist producer and songwriter
blasphemer and even though two long-time
mayhem fans this loss may seem
significant no matter how bloody it was
a lineup changes never really stopped
mayhem from sounding hellish before so I
don't see why it would now just like the
band who made it this record lives up to
its name esoteric warfare the album
features that classic old-school lo-fi
necro style of black metal production
getting into this record sonic details
involves wading through a waist-deep
swamp of Sonic muck and the other side
of the coin is warfare this record is
looking for a battle but it is a skilled
and calculated and sinister warrior this
LP is straightforward black metal with
some occasionally angular and
progressive riffs and odd grooves here
and there a little like chimera
but maybe it touch more experimental and
not nearly as well recorded but
discography comparisons aside get into
the cell P if you're looking for some
ruthless dark dismal black metal riffing
some sharp melodies some really brittle
shimmering guitar tones relentless
drumming and a lot of the time some
experimental odd instrumental detours
and interludes like on the songs I wore
around the 1:30 mark you're getting this
wall of whispers and lo fie guitars
which is significantly softer than many
other moments on this track or on the
song Watchers we're all of a sudden
Attila breaks into this throat singing
the guitars your way drone ear or the
song Trinity all of a sudden the guitars
died down there's all these sirens what
sounds like gunshots there's some death
metal growls work later into this track
as well atilla's vocal performances
overall on this record are pretty
diverse if you're familiar with his
career this is not the freakiest you've
ever heard him but he does bring a lot
of vocal styles to the table from the
traditional black metal wretch to some
truly evil shouting - aah nearly every
song on this LP features some kind of
abrupt change or sudden detour and I
would call it just window dressing but I
think the ideas that mayhem brings
through these changes are usually pretty
novel however the first half of this LP
I think does run a little average in
terms of just a black metal sound but on
the second half of this LP I think
mayhem experiments a little more boldly
especially around the halfway point
where the songs tend to slow down a
little bit get a little noisier get a
little bit more atmospheric and the more
aggressive tracks on the side of the
record like corpse of care and throne of
time I think these songs are actually
more vicious and freakish overall this
is a fine mayhem album not necessarily
the crushing return one would want after
seven years but certainly a great late
era record there's a lot of musical
detail on this LP there's musical
diversity there's personality there's
experimentation there's eccentricity
mayhem do a great job of balancing
between making metal music that is
animalistic and thought-provoking I do
think the production is lacking
sometimes
pulls away from the potential punch of
this record atilla's vocals definitely
could have used more space especially
when he goes into his lower register
they tend to sound a little suffocated
and the bass drums on this record for as
fantastically as they are played by
Hellhammer who plays at speeds that just
are mind-boggling they are so
overpowering and tend to drown out the
subtleties and the guitars and really
just overtake the entire song especially
on the first few tracks and the really
flat plastic tone of these bass drums
don't really do these tracks any favors
either still I think this is a flavorful
killer and solid black metal record I'm
feeling a decent strong seven on this
thing transition if you've given this
record to listen what did you think did
you love it did you hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it Anthony Fantan Oh mayhem
forever
